title: Biden Expected to Nominate Tom Vilsack to Lead Agriculture Department
summary: Vilsack led the Agriculture Department from 2009 to early 2017. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden is expected to nominate former Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack to return to his role leading the federal agency, according to people familiar with the plans.

title: Bankrupt Ann Taylor Owner Gets Green Light for Sale Despite DOJ Objection
summary: Ascena Retail Group hopes to wrap up the $540 million sale out of bankruptcy to Sycamore Partners before the holidays. Ascena Retail Group Inc. has won court approval to sell its Ann Taylor, Lane Bryant, Loft and Lou & Grey retail brands out of bankruptcy to private-equity firm Sycamore Partners in a deal valued at about $1 billion.

title: Seeing Higher Education With New Eyes
summary: How should universities change, given the experience of the pandemic?. Editor's note: This week's Future View discusses how universities should change, given the experience of the pandemic. Next week we'll ask, "Has higher education been dumbed down in the switch to remote learning? If so, how?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Dec. 15. The best responses will be published that night.

title: The Fannie and Freddie Conundrum
summary: A regulator's plan to recapitalize the firms is the least worst option.. Politics sometimes requires choosing the least bad option. That may be the best way to assess the Federal Housing Finance Agency's (FHFA) eleventh-hour push to release government-sponsored enterprises Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from their 12-year captivity.

title: Trump's Defense Bill Kamikaze Run
summary: His veto threat could end up hurting his own policy priorities.. President Trump deserves credit for rebuilding America's armed forces, so it's a pity his parting shot is a veto spectacle over a defense policy bill. Mr. Trump won't extract what he wants but he might harm some of his own priorities with friendly fire.

title: Another General at Defense?
summary: Lloyd Austin's record and views are more important than his race.. Joe Biden has picked retired Gen. Lloyd Austin to be his Defense Secretary, and anyone skimming the coverage might believe the most important recommendation is his race. But Senators interested more in substance than identity politics have plenty to think about.

title: Musk Says CEOs' Focus Often Misdirected
summary: Tesla chief suggests business leaders focus more on improving products and services, less on spreadsheets. Elon Musk has advice for America's CEOs: Quit spending so much time in meetings.

title: Chuck Yeager
summary: The combat pilot who broke the sound barrier with two broken ribs.. There aren't many giants in American life, and on Monday we lost another. Chuck Yeager, the first man to travel faster than the speed of sound, died in his home at the age of 97.

title: The Best Herd Immunity Money Can Buy
summary: Paying people to get the Covid-19 shot may be the way to overcome skepticism about the vaccine.. How much would the government have to pay you to take the Covid-19 vaccine?

title: A Nasdaq Chief's Diversity Stunt
summary: Americans tire of seeing institutions misused for personal aggrandizement.. It was always possible that Donald Trump's relentlessly meretricious self-promotion would have the opposite of the effect on "norms" that the hand-wringers fretted about. But there is also evidence, we must admit, for the counter theory.

title: The Economy Needs a Little More PPP
summary: The next version of the Paycheck Protection Program should focus on helping smaller firms.. With the coronavirus surging and colder weather limiting outdoor activities, the economy needs another round of fiscal policy support. Aid to small businesses should be part of any federal package, but it should be structured somewhat differently than the original Paycheck Protection Program.

title: Paralyzed by Polio in 1951, My Mother Didn't Give Up
summary: Doctors, nurses, therapists and scientists worked to find treatments while waiting for a vaccine.. My mother, Myrna Nielson Thacker, got polio just after Thanksgiving 1951, when she was 14. She had spent the long weekend with family in Salt Lake City. On returning home 50 miles south in Spanish Fork, she experienced a fever, numbness and stiffness in her feet and legs, and excruciating pain in her back. Within a few days, she was paralyzed from the waist down.

title: No More Bishop Nice Guy
summary: Religious leaders have been too deferential to unreasonable Covid restrictions.. The Bronx, N.Y.

title: 'Friends and Enemies' Review: Making Her Own Black List
summary: A gimlet-eyed chronicle of a glamorous and tumultuous life in journalism that spares no one, least of all the author herself.. Barbara Amiel is the wife of Conrad Black, the newspaper tycoon who was convicted of fraud and went to prison in 2008. Now, a year and a half after his pardon from President Donald Trump, comes her memoir, a tome nearly 600 pages long. When it comes to those who have crossed her, the word "pardon" is not in her lexicon.

title: Supreme Court Denies GOP Bid to Block Pennsylvania Results for Biden
summary: No justice notes a dissent to order. The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected a last-ditch Republican request to block President-elect Joe Biden's victory in Pennsylvania, dealing another blow to supporters of President Trump who have contested the Nov. 3 election across the country.

title: WSJ CEO Council Kicks Off
summary: Event featured Elon Musk, Jake Sullivan, Cedric Richmond, Mark Milley, Deborah Birx, Anthony Fauci, Justin Trudeau and more. The Wall Street Journal's CEO Council summit kicked off Monday evening and continued Tuesday, featuring interviews with prominent lawmakers, health-care and national-security officials, business leaders, economists and more.

title: Conservative Lawsuits Fuel Distrust of Election Results
summary: Legal challenges have been unsuccessful but could lay groundwork for movement to change voting laws. Phill Kline says he has filed so many legal challenges to the presidential-election results that he can't keep track.

title: U.S. Cyber Firm FireEye Says It Was Breached by Nation-State Hackers
summary: The cybersecurity company said the attack compromised its software tools used to test the defenses of its thousands of customers. WASHINGTON-U.S.-based FireEye Inc., one of the world's largest cybersecurity firms, was hacked in what it said was a highly sophisticated foreign-government attack that compromised its software tools used to test the defenses of its thousands of customers.

title: Education Department Blasts 'Culture of Censorship' at Colleges
summary: Officials say sensitivity over potentially offensive views is stifling free speech and academic inquiry. The Education Department has set up a hotline where students and staff can report concerns about free-speech violations on college campuses, the latest effort by the Trump administration to ensure conservative or otherwise unpopular views are respected at schools they say can hew too liberal.

title: Senate Approves Trump's Pick for FCC
summary: Republican lawyer Nathan Simington is confirmed for five-year FCC term over Democrat objections. President Trump's nominee to join the Federal Communications Commission was confirmed by the Senate on Tuesday, setting up a possible partisan deadlock at the telecommunications regulator when Democrats take power next year.

title: Biden's Pick for Defense Chief Rekindles a Civilian-Military Debate
summary: Gen. Austin will need a congressional waiver, as did Gen. Mattis, posing a test for Democrats. President-elect Joe Biden's pick of retired Army Gen. Lloyd Austinas his defense secretary has renewed debate about civil-military relations, putting congressional Democrats in the awkward position of defending a move they had criticized four years ago.

title: U.S. Real-Estate Investors Seek Hollywood Dreams in London
summary: As Covid-19 boosts demand for content, L.A. firm bets on Eastbrook Studios and Pinewood plans to expand. U.S. and other global property investors are putting billions of dollars into a significant expansion of new production studios in the U.K., where tax breaks are attracting business from movie makers and television companies.

title: Former Allergan CEO's SPAC Agrees to $1.1 Billion Merger With Beauty Products Company
summary: HydraFacial's private-equity owners, Linden Capital Partners and DW Healthcare Partners, will retain a combined 25% stake in the business following the merger. A blank-check company backed by former Allergan PLC Chief Executive Brent Saunders is set to merge with a private equity-backed health and beauty company in a deal valued at $1.1 billion.

title: Stitch Fix Shoppers See the Light
summary: Latest results from newfangled clothes seller bode well for its future. As traditional bricks-and-mortar retailers continue to endure sales declines, Stitch Fix 's quarterly results released Monday afternoon show how the experience of shopping for clothes could be changing for good.

title: New York City Council Eyes Bill to End Solitary Confinement
summary: Bill to end the controversial practice in city jails is set to be introduced this week. Nearly six months after Mayor Bill de Blasio pledged to end solitary confinement as a means of punishment in New York City's jail system, the city council this week is set to begin fast-tracking the process by reviewing new legislation to halt the controversial practice.

title: Judge Dismisses Flynn Case, Denounces Government's Role
summary: Former national security adviser had been pardoned by Trump after pleading guilty to lying to FBI. WASHINGTON-A federal judge officially closed the criminal case against former national security adviser Mike Flynn, who was pardoned by President Trump, but suggested that the Justice Department's handling of the matter was highly irregular and potentially improper.

title: Side Effects, Efficacy and Other Takeaways on Pfizer Covid Vaccine
summary: FDA report on inoculation goes to outside advisory panel Thursday. Here are key findings of the Food and Drug Administration's analysis of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Pfizer and German partner BioNTech, as well as findings from the manufacturers. Both reports were released Tuesday.

title: U.S. Sanctions Chinese Firms Over North Korean Coal
summary: Sanctions are the latest action against Beijing for allegedly helping Pyongyang evade U.N. sanctions. WASHINGTON-The U.S. on Tuesday blacklisted several Chinese companies for allegedly helping North Korea export its coal, part of a renewed effort by the Trump administration to stem critical revenue sources for Kim Jong Un's regime.

title: Nasdaq Defends Its New Diversity Mandate
summary: Our disclosure-based proposal provides investors with greater transparency about board composition.. The opinions expressed in the editorials "The Woke Nasdaq" (Dec. 2) and "Nasdaq vs. Warren Buffett" (Dec. 3) distort Nasdaq 's proposed new listing requirements. Nasdaq is not asking the SEC to "impose a quota system," nor are we "mandating" the composition of boards.

title: The Human Cost of Massive Plant Closures
summary: So much in the stories of these GM workers who left their families behind when the factory in Lordstown, Ohio, shut down, my dad experienced as well.. "Closed GM Factory Spawns Wave of Industrial Migrants" (Page One, Nov. 30) left me in tears, as it reminded me of my father's sacrifice for his family. In the early 1980s, my dad lost a good factory job with Clark Equipment Co. in Jackson, Mich. After two years of unemployment, he finally found another good-paying job 200 miles away with BorgWarner. During my freshman year in high school, my dad moved into an apartment in Muncie, Ind.

title: Louis Pasteur Had Good Advice About Luck and Life
summary: We should appreciate our good luck when good things come our way.. Bob Brody's "It's Thanksgiving, as Luck Would Have It" (op-ed, Nov. 25) rightly suggests we should appreciate our good luck when good things come our way. He notes that attitudes and behavior can influence our luck, possibly steering us away from bad luck. His piece reminded me of one of my favorite ironic quotes, attributed to Louis Pasteur: "Chance only favors the mind which is prepared."

title: The First Amendment, Churches and Public Health
summary: We wear masks, sanitize our hands, sit two pews apart in assigned seats. We don't sing at all. We don't "inhale and exhale forcefully" while praying. Oh, and we register for contact tracing every time we attend Mass.. Robert Sommers posits that "quickly" going in and out of the liquor store is less likely to spread the coronavirus than attending church (Letters, Dec. 3). In the Archdiocese of Chicago, which ministers to 2.2. million Catholics, we wear masks, sanitize our hands (two times after entering church), sit two pews apart in assigned seats, with only two to four people per pew (depending on family size). We don't sing at all. We don't "inhale and exhale forcefully" while praying. Oh, and we register for contact tracing every time we attend Mass.

title: Pompeo Warns Businesses Over Hong Kong as U.S.-China Tensions Rise
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam says Beijing-backed national-security law has improved stability, making for better business climate. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who this week unveiled sanctions over China's actions in Hong Kong, warned business leaders that the U.S. will treat the city, a global trade and financial center, the same way as mainland China.

title: Apple to Sell AirPods Max Over-the-Ear Headphones
summary: Expansion of product lineup is direct strike against companies like Bose and Sony. Apple Inc. on Tuesday revealed plans to sell AirPods-branded over-the-ear headphones, an expansion of its product lineup in a direct strike against companies such as Bose Corp. and Sony Corp.

title: Glitch in the Museum Matrix
summary: Large-scale virtual presentations of famous works of art obscure rather than illuminate their sources..

title: FDA Says Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine Is Safe, Effective
summary: Favorable analysis paves way for approval as early as this weekend. The Food and Drug Administration said the first Covid-19 vaccine being considered for U.S. distribution "met the prescribed success criteria" in a clinical study, paving the way for the agency to green-light distribution as early as this weekend.

title: S&P 500, Nasdaq Close at Records
summary: A turnaround in technology stocks helped pull the main stock market gauges back into positive territory. U.S. stocks rose Tuesday, propelling the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite to fresh records following a pair of positive steps toward combating the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: 'Safe Harbor' Day Marks Further Step Toward Sealing Biden's Victory
summary: States are supposed to resolve election disputes by Tuesday, and if they do, Congress should accept the results under federal law. A federal deadline Tuesday marks the latest formal step toward confirming President-elect Joe Biden's victory in the 2020 election, further reducing options for President Trump and his supporters to fight the results.

title: 'The Surgeon's Cut' Review: Where 'Miracle' Is the Operative Word
summary: A Netflix series offers gripping documentary portraits of four remarkable doctors.. As unlikely as it sounds, "The Surgeon's Cut" is really about artists. Their métier may be on the margins of medical science-heart transplants, brain surgery, liver grafting, procedures inside the womb-but their personalities are as large, singular and even eccentric as the most "creative" individuals. They possess the same kind of vision and the same kind of drive. What they manage to do is create miracles. What the program's four directors create-let's call it a minor miracle-is something that does justice to their subjects.

title: 'Wolfwalkers' Review: An Irish Enchantment
summary: Likely to captivate viewers young and old, an animated film roots its fantastical story in the island's tortured history.. 'Family entertainment" often means something parents can sit through without clawing the armrest off the couch. But the animated "Wolfwalkers" is a different sort of beast. With its enchanted forests, shape-shifting wood sprites and a plucky heroine named Robyn Goodfellowe, the film is terrific fare for kids. But the underpinnings of its fantastical story lie in tortured Irish history, English imperialism, and the use of religion to rationalize oppression; there's a hum of yearning for a pre-Christian Hibernia of pagans, Druids and nature worship. Adults will be eager to see where it's all going to go.

title: Treasury Yields Slip on Brexit Struggles, Stimulus Worries
summary: Yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury declines for second straight session. U.S. government-bond yields fell Tuesday, driven lower by investors' concerns about the prospects for Brexit trade negotiations and a U.S. emergency economic relief package.

title: Spy vs. Spy (Wednesday Crossword, December 9)
For Some Sellers, Permanent Fixtures Remain Forever Theirs
summary: Real-estate agents recall clients who took built-in appliances and toilet seats along with them. Konstantin Zaliznyak

title: Apple Replays the Wrong Audio Track
summary: New AirPods Max headphones may follow HomePod rather than AirPods trajectory. Apple Inc.'s new headphones are at least aptly named.

title: What to Do-and Not Do-in the Aftermath of a Breach
summary: Among the most-important: Don't create fear and uncertainty by firing the people who may know best how to recover from the attack. The immediate aftermath of a breach is a critical time for the hacked organization. If leaders don't learn quickly what went wrong and act swiftly-in the right ways-to fix the problem, they risk exacerbating the damage in terms of financial and reputational harm.

title: China Aims to Outpace U.S. Militarily, American Commander Says
summary: Beijing wants to match U.S. capabilities by 2035 and surpass them by midcentury, Gen. Milley says, echoing concerns in Pentagon report. China is seeking to invest its economic growth into equaling American military capabilities by 2035 and aims to be able to defeat the U.S. in an armed conflict by midcentury, the top U.S. military commander said.

title: Can We Make Our Sex Lives Fun Again?
summary: Few people report feeling sexy in the pandemic. But there are ways to reignite the spark.. How's your sex life?

title: Boeing Makes First 737 MAX Delivery Since Lifting of FAA Ban
summary: United Airlines receives the first MAX planes after regulators grounded the jet in March 2019 following two crashes. Boeing Co. has delivered a 737 MAX to United Airlines Holdings Inc., the first carrier to receive a newly produced model of the jet after U.S. regulators ended a nearly two-year grounding last month.

title: Meet the Frankenshirt. It's Three (or Seven) Shirts in One
summary: Labels like Burberry and Marni are selling curious men's shirts cobbled together from motley fabrics and patterns. Enticingly trendy or just terrifying?. THERE'S A JOKEY line that men's fashion designers rely on when presenting a collection of glaringly ho-hum button-ups and blazers: "What do you expect me to create, a shirt with three sleeves?" The remark is hammy, reflexive, but I get it. When you consider anatomical limitations and the constraints of good taste, designers can only rejigger men's staples so many ways.

title: New Jersey Starts $190 Million Makeover of Newark Penn Station
summary: First phase to include restoring benches in waiting area, updating bathrooms, scrubbing exterior. NJ Transit has begun a $190 million renovation and modernization of its transportation hub in New Jersey's largest city, Newark.

title: Michigan-Ohio State Game Is Off, Complicating Playoff Picture
summary: The storied football rivalry between the Wolverines and Buckeyes won't be played for the first time since 1917 thanks to a Covid outbreak on Michigan's team.. The coronavirus pandemic has wiped out this year's edition of one of the most storied rivalries in college football, as Michigan announced Tuesday that it will not play Ohio State this weekend due to a continuing outbreak on the Wolverines roster.

title: Data Privacy in the Age of Online Learning
summary: Coronavirus forced school districts across the country to move rapidly to online learning. That has some privacy experts concerned.. Schools are relying heavily on technology-from videoconferencing programs to digital-teaching tools and temperature-taking apps-to educate children safely in the age of Covid.

title: How to Make the Housing Market More Equitable
summary: Resume Subscription. Author

title: California Chicken Processor Reopens Plant After Deep Cleaning for Coronavirus
summary: Meat producers have been spending on safety initiatives to prevent and contain coronavirus outbreaks and keep plants operating. Foster Farms, a major chicken processor in California, said it reopened a facility in the state after Covid-19 testing demonstrated that about 14% of its workforce there had recently contracted the virus but wasn't showing symptoms.

title: Some McDonald's Franchisees Plan Higher Happy Meal Prices
summary: The burger giant is raising fees and ending a rebate on the children's menu for U.S. restaurant operators. Some McDonald's Corp. franchisees said they would raise prices on Happy Meals after the company revokes a longstanding rebate, escalating tensions between the fast-food giant and U.S. restaurant operators.

title: Celebrity Plastic Surgeon Trims Price of Bel-Air Megamansion From $180 Million to $99 Million
summary: Dr. Raj Kanodia lowered the listing price after Bruce Makowsky's home next door sold for less than half its original ask. In the summer of 2018, two newly built, enormous mansions sitting next to each other in a swanky Bel-Air neighborhood represented the peak of Los Angeles's high-end building boom: One house sought $188 million, the other $180 million.

title: A Plastic Surgeon's Massive Bel-Air Spec Home
summary: Raj Kanodia's property comes with lots of glass and landscaping. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: World Bank Chief Sees Slow Global Recovery From Covid-19 Slump
summary: David Malpass says it will take two to three years to return to pre-pandemic levels of output as many developing nations struggle. WASHINGTON-It will take two to three years for global output to return to pre-pandemic levels as many developing nations slowly climb out the coronavirus-induced slump with the help of vaccines, World Bank President David Malpass said.

title: U.K. Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout: Coronavirus Shots Now Available
summary: Britain moved faster than the U.S. and Europe to designate the vaccine safe and effective for use. The U.K. became the first Western country to start inoculating its population with a Covid-19 vaccine developed by Pfizer Inc. and Germany's BioNTech SE . Maggie Keenan, 90 years old, received the first shot at a hospital in Coventry early Tuesday morning in a program that could provide a taste of the logistical challenges facing other countries, including the U.S., as they prepare to roll out their own large-scale vaccination plans.

title: Fauci Calls Coronavirus Vaccine a Game Changer, Decries Misinformation
summary: Deborah Birx, White House coronavirus-response coordinator, reiterates call for states to use public-health measures. Anthony Fauci said a vaccine could diminish coronavirus as successfully as the polio vaccine did for polio, enabling workers to return to offices and restaurants in the second half of 2021.

title: Johnson Prepares for Crunch Brexit Talks
summary: British prime minister will meet with the European Commission president for face-to-face talks on Wednesday. Brexit negotiations are set to enter a last decisive phase as British Prime Minister Boris Johnson prepares to travel to Brussels on Wednesday in a bid to secure a deal over the European Union's relations with the U.K.

title: Portugal Joins Negative-Rates Club With Benchmark Bond
summary: The country's 10-year government bond yield slips below zero, joining certain other European countries. Portugal's benchmark bond traded with a negative yield, signaling investors' increasingly relaxed attitudes toward a country that was once among the worst-hit by the European debt crisis.

title: AT&T Boss Defends Plans to Stream Warner Bros. Films Upon Release
summary: CEO John Stankey expects coronavirus pandemic to scare many people away from theaters. AT&T Inc. Chief Executive John Stankey defended the decision to release all Warner Bros. movies online the same day they hit theaters next year, arguing that the film producer had to tweak a 2020 playbook that wasn't working during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Tesla Is Watching Its Stock Price Too
summary: Elon Musk is smart to turn paper gains into cash, and speculators would be wise to follow his example. Tesla is wisely ringing the cash register amid a stunning stock rally. Speculators should take notice.

title: AstraZeneca Vaccine Data Underscore Safety, Range of Efficacy
summary: U.K. drugmaker says it will pursue emergency authorization for the shot and let regulators decide on dosing. LONDON-Peer-reviewed data from late-stage human trials of a Covid-19 vaccine developed by the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca PLC reaffirmed the shot's strong safety results and provided some additional evidence that halving the first of two doses of the shot boosts its effectiveness.

title: Emirati Acquires 50% of Israeli Soccer Team Known for Racist Fans
summary: Sheikh Hamad says partnership aims 'to set an example...that Jews and Muslims can work together'. An Emirati investor has acquired a 50% stake in a popular Israeli soccer club that is known for a group of racist, anti-Arab fans, one of the first high-profile deals since Israel and the United Arab Emirates normalized relations in September.

title: TikTok Download Ban Is Blocked by Second Judge
summary: Ruling follows similar decision in case brought by the app's content creators. A second federal judge has blocked the Trump administration's attempt to ban TikTok downloads in the U.S., underscoring the dwindling legal options the Trump administration has to pursue an outright ban of the popular app.

title: Profit Keeps Corporate Leaders Honest
summary: 'Stakeholder capitalism' allows the Davos crowd to obfuscate what counts as success for a business.. The World Economic Forum knows never to let a good crisis go to waste. The organization behind the famous conference of politicians, executives, celebrities and "thought leaders" at Davos is now promoting an initiative called "The Great Reset." The idea is to repackage shibboleths of the technocratic center-left for the marketing opportunity presented by Covid-19.

title: States and Cities Deserve Taxpayer Support
summary: Covid relief is no 'blue-state bailout.' The virus doesn't respect political boundaries.. As Congress presses to complete an emergency Covid-19 relief bill, aid to states and localities continues to be a point of contention. But the novel coronavirus respects neither geographical boundaries nor partisan affiliations. Heartland states that thought they were safe turned rapidly into hot spots. As the costs of caring for the sick and trying to protect the healthy have surged, tax revenue has declined sharply. Most states and cities have responded by cutting their budgets while hoping for some assistance from the federal government. Without it, they will be forced to make even deeper cuts.

title: U.K. Begins Rollout of Pfizer Vaccine in a First for the West
summary: Resume Subscription. CARDIFF, Wales-The U.K. became the first Western country to start distributing a Covid-19 vaccine to its population, rolling out a mass inoculation program that could provide a template for other countries, including the U.S., of the practicalities and potential pitfalls of vaccinating at speed and scale.

title: These Are the Colleges That Leave Parents With the Most Debt
summary: Art schools, historically Black colleges and small private colleges have the largest parent debt burdens, an analysis of fresh data shows. Typical families at dozens of schools are borrowing almost $100,000 to finance student education, data from the U.S. Education Department show. The figures reveal the amount of debt parents took on through a federal college loan program called Parent Plus. The data "provides a more complete financial picture of how recent graduates have paid for their postsecondary education, especially if their parents took on debt to help them cover some or all of the costs," the Education Department said in a statement last week.

title: In Portland, Tensions Move From Streets to Court
summary: Federal prosecutors, defense lawyers spar over charges against 90 individuals in Oregon. The tensions that erupted in protests and violence for more than three months on the streets of Portland this summer are now moving into a quieter venue: the courts.

title: Michael Bassik Leaves MDC to Resurrect Brooklyn Magazine and Sell Sprinkles
summary: CEO of MDC Partners media agency Assembly is leaving to start ventures including a flavored sprinkles company and a health-data business. Political marketing veteran Michael Bassik has left the advertising holding company MDC Partners Inc. to relaunch Brooklyn Magazine and start a flurry of other ventures, including a flavored sprinkle brand and a health-data firm.

title: China Floats Covid-19 Theories That Point to Foreign Origins, Frozen Food
summary: As WHO prepares probe into start of pandemic, scientists chafe at politicization of research. HONG KONG-China is aggressively advancing alternative theories about the source of the coronavirus that causes Covid-19, muddying the waters as the World Health Organization prepares to launch a long-awaited investigation into the origins of the pandemic.

title: First He Sold Ferraris. Then Jonathan Waxman Learned to Cook
summary: How a matchbook kicked off the celebrity chef's culinary career. Jonathan Waxman, 70, is a chef and pioneer of California-Italian cuisine who owns restaurants in Nashville, Atlanta and New York. He is the author of "The Barbuto Cookbook" (Abrams). He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Betterment CEO Jon Stein Steps Down
summary: Investment-advice firm chief to be succeeded by former ViacomCBS executive Sarah Kirshbaum Levy. Betterment LLC founder Jon Stein is stepping down as chief executive, the investment-advice company said Tuesday. He will be succeeded by Sarah Kirshbaum Levy, a former executive of ViacomCBS Inc.

title: BlueCrest Capital Management to Pay $170 Million to Settle SEC Claims
summary: Firm misled clients about an internal fund that invested its traders' own money, SEC says. BlueCrest Capital Management Ltd. will pay $170 million to settle claims that it misled clients about an internal fund that invested its traders' own money, while its flagship fund was managed by an underperforming algorithm, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday.

title: Tesla Plans Stock Sale, Closing Year of Soaring Gains
summary: The electric-vehicle company will sell up to $5 billion of new shares over time at market prices. Tesla Inc. plans to raise as much as $5 billion through new sales of stock, capitalizing on a market tear that has sent its shares zooming this year.

title: How an Energy Startup's Plan to Disrupt the Power Grid Got Disrupted
summary: Resume Subscription. Bloom Energy Corp. became a hot startup more than a decade ago by promising to upset the utility industry with devices that could power the nation's buildings. Today, it's a reminder of how a rapidly changing industry can foil even the most driven entrepreneurs.

title: A New York Penthouse 1,000 Feet Above Street Level Fetches $50 Million-Plus
summary: The contract for an apartment at 111 West 57th Street is one of the biggest signed in New York since the start of the pandemic. A penthouse apartment at 111 West 57th Street, an under-construction ultra-skinny tower on New York's Billionaires' Row, has gone into contract for over $50 million, according to a person familiar with the transaction. The deal, signed in early November, is one of the priciest publicly disclosed contracts to have been signed in New York since the onset of the pandemic.

title: U.S. Steel to Buy Remaining Stake in New, Low-Cost Steel Mill
summary: Rising steel prices helped company to raise cash to complete purchase of Big River Steel sooner than expected. United States Steel Corp. has agreed to acquire the remaining 50.1% stake in Big River Steel LLC for $774 million, giving the steelmaker ownership of one of the newest, most advanced steel mills in the country.

title: Uber Pays Up to Take Back Seat on Driverless Cars
summary: The ride-hailing giant won't have to consolidate the costs of automating driving, but will remain invested. In a sign of investors' meager appetite for driverless-car ventures, Uber Technologies Inc. isn't so much selling its ill-fated project as paying a rival to take it on.

title: Howard Stern Extends SiriusXM Contract for 5 Years
summary: Stern will continue to produce and host his show exclusively for the satellite-radio company. Howard Stern is staying with SiriusXM for another five years.

title: Socially Distant Santa Is Coming to Town
summary: Resume Subscription. Carleigh Hansen's visit to Santa Claus at the Park Meadows Mall in Lone Tree, Colo., was a little different this year from Christmases past. The 8-year-old still wore a new dress for pictures and her mother treated her to cheesecake afterward. But this time, Santa wore a face shield and sat behind a sheet of plexiglass. Carleigh passed him her list underneath the barrier and talked to him through an intercom system.

title: 'Tis the Season to Buy Local
summary: Buying gifts at New York City mom-and-pop stores can be more expensive than online retail, but the experience is priceless. This year, I vowed, I wouldn't do any holiday shopping online, or at the big chains. Instead, I'd buy all my gifts from the city's struggling mom-and-pops. And yes, Virginia, I discovered it's entirely possible get all your holiday shopping done at New York City's little storefronts. But that doesn't mean it's easy or cheap.

title: Trump Won New York's Suffolk County. Why That Signals Hope for Democrats.
summary: Razor-thin margin in most populous county carried by President Trump gives Democrats hope an urban electoral coalition is putting down deeper roots. Huntington, N.Y.-Suffolk County was the most populous county in the U.S. that President Trump won in 2020, winning the New York City suburb by just 232 votes, according to election results certified in recent days.

title: How DoorDash Pulled Ahead in Food-Delivery War
summary: Startup's IPO comes after a year of aggressive growth. Is it built to last?. Food-delivery company DoorDash Inc. is set to go public this week, valued at more than $30 billion. Here is a look at how the San Francisco-based startup has leapfrogged rivals to become the dominant player in a competitive market.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Superior Energy Files for Bankruptcy; J.C. Penney Completes Sale, Lines Up Loans From Wells Fargo; SBA Opposes PPP Recipient's Plan
summary: Resume Subscription. Good day. Superior Energy became the latest oil and gas drilling services company to file for chapter 11, while J.C. Penney said it is exiting bankruptcy and has closed a deal to sell its operations to mall owners. The Small Business Administraion took issue with Astria Health's restructuring plan.

title: Stitch Fix, Tesla, Peloton: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. legislators are still hashing out the details of a coronavirus-relief package. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Tuesday.

title: Imagine a Nutrition Label-for Cybersecurity
summary: As the Internet-of-Things proliferates, consumers want to know how their data will be used by the makers of devices-before they buy them. Your milk and orange juice have nutrition labels. Soon your refrigerator and coffee maker could, too.

title: Long-Awaited 5G Auction Expected to Stretch Carriers
summary: Wireless companies including Verizon expected to splurge on U.S. auction of C-band spectrum. Verizon Communications Inc. and other cellphone providers are expected to spend billions of dollars to secure prized spectrum for their 5G networks in a U.S. government sale that kicks off Tuesday.

title: A Nonprofit That Uncovered Hundreds of Lost Works by Female Artists to Close
summary: Advancing Women Artists was founded by the late pioneering philanthropist known as 'Indiana Jane'; the closure comes as a surprise. Florence

title: Powered by Apple Watch, Fitness+ Builds a Virtual Home Gym
summary: Fitness+, Apple's new subscription service for on-demand workouts, arrives next week with 21 trainers across 10 disciplines.. The fact that Apple's six-country launch of a new connected workout platform, Fitness+, which arrives next week, is happening during a surge in a global pandemic that carved out a new market for home fitness is, Apple insists, pure coincidence ("Siri, what's a synonym for providential?")

title: How Coronavirus Changed This Colorado Restaurant's Work Culture
summary: Pêche, a restaurant in a remote part of Colorado, opened with a kinder work culture that has helped it survive the pandemic. The pork belly at Pêche arrives at the table still sizzling in a small cast-iron skillet, nestled against a sunny-side-up duck egg. The waiter then instructs diners to mix in a bowl of fresh greens that wilt after absorbing pork fat and heat. The dish reminds me of a spinach salad recipe from my childhood, in which just-cooked, bite-size pieces of bacon and spoonfuls of bacon fat, still warm, were tossed with raw spinach to dress and slightly cook the greens. In dishes like this at Pêche, chef Matt Chasseur has sourced something deeply familiar from our collective consciousness, excavated elemental flavors and textures, then radically improved them.

title: Lessons From Fall Reopenings Change Colleges' Future Plans
summary: Some schools aim to increase in-person offerings and testing next term; others intend to scale back or focus on wastewater monitoring. The fall semester brought nearly impossible choices for universities and colleges: Reopening for in-person classes meant risking a Covid-19 outbreak, while keeping students home paved the way for financial losses.

title: How to Motivate Teens Struggling With Remote Learning
summary: Getting boys to engage in virtual instruction doesn't have to be a battle. Experts offer tips on how to make virtual school more bearable.. We're nine months into the pandemic and remote school is wearing on students. Boys, who are at greater risk of falling behind academically than girls, are having an especially tough time with all the hours spent behind screens. The challenges of staying focused and motivated in remote school carry even higher stakes for adolescent and teenage boys, who face more academic pressure than younger ones.

title: U.S. Aims to Check Real-Estate Data Giant CoStar's Expansion in Multifamily
summary: FTC last week authorized a federal lawsuit against CoStar's plan to acquire RentPath Holdings. The U.S. government is trying for a second time to limit the steady expansion of real-estate data giant CoStar Group Inc., by moving to block its latest proposed acquisition in the rental apartment listing business.

title: Surge in Physical Threats During Pandemic Complicates Employee Security Efforts
summary: Security consultants say companies are looking for ways to manage increased threats targeting a workforce that is less secure and more spread out. High-profile executives and rank-and-file staff have faced increased physical threats this year from inside and outside their companies, leading corporate security teams to search for ways to better protect employees-particularly those working from home, security executives say.

title: Japan Pulls Back From Cash Handouts in Covid-19 Response
summary: Prime Minister Suga sees pandemic as chance for longer-term growth but is more cautious than U.S., Europe on quick stimulus. Japan is forswearing nationwide cash handouts or other big spending that would give its economy an immediate lift, taking a more long-term approach than the U.S.

title: Mount Everest Just Got Taller
summary: China and Nepal jointly announced a new official height of 29,032 feet for the world's tallest mountain. KATHMANDU, Nepal-Mount Everest just got a little taller.

title: Mexican Cartels Are Cooking Chinese Chemicals in Dutch Meth Labs
summary: Narco gangs piggyback legal business networks to tap rich markets world-wide. MOERDIJK, Netherlands-When police raided a barge moored here last year, they found more than just a sophisticated crystal meth lab that started sinking as they inspected it.

title: Wellington Amasses Up to $2.2 Billion for Late-Stage Deals
summary: The asset manager has closed its third late-stage growth fund with $1.8 billion and may have another $400 million available for co-investing in deals. Wellington Management Co. has rounded up as much as $2.2 billion to back late-stage startups as they look to navigate their way to the public markets.

title: China's Riskier Companies Pay Up to Raise Bond Financing
summary: Firms rated below triple-A paid their highest average yield since early 2019. Investors are cooling on debt from riskier Chinese companies after missed payments by state-backed firms have cast doubt on the reliability of government support.

title: China Car Sales Rise Again, Cementing Pandemic Recovery
summary: To boost sales, government has been easing purchasing quotas and giving subsidies to car buyers. Car sales in China, the world's largest auto market, rose for a fifth straight month in November, as strong demand and policy stimulus continued to cement the recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Nielsen Sets Timeline for Big Change in TV Ratings
summary: The country's leading TV-ratings firm plans a metric that measures content and ads across TV and digital media. Nielsen said it would replace its current TV ratings system by 2024 with a metric that incorporates digital viewing including streaming TV as well as the current traditional audiences, a shift that could transform how TV and digital video ads are bought and sold in the future.

title: Vaccine Passports Could Help Life Return to Normal, but Experts Urge Caution
summary: Requirement to prove immunity raises practical and ethical issues: Should vaccinated people have greater freedom?. As the West's first authorized Covid-19 shots were administered in the U.K., an old ethical question in public health is gaining new relevance: Is there a case for issuing proof of immunity to people who have been inoculated?

title: Greek Banks Turn Corner With Bad Loans
summary: State-backed securitization program helps usher in global investors even during pandemic. Greek banks, among Europe's weakest, are getting rid of their bad loans at a healthy clip.

title: Covid-19, Remote Work Make Austin a Magnet for New Jobs
summary: Resume Subscription. The pandemic and the prospect of working remotely have spawned an exodus from New York and San Francisco to sunnier, more-affordable cities. Few have benefited more than Austin.

title: Environmental Groups Seek Access to Records on Oil-Drilling Safety-Rule Changes
summary: Sierra Club and others hope to overturn Trump administration's partial rollback of the 'well-control rule' passed after 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster. WASHINGTON-The Sierra Club and other environmental groups are asking a federal judge for access to a swath of internal Interior Department documents as they seek to restore offshore oil-drilling safety rules scaled back by the Trump administration.

title: JD Health Makes Strong Debut in Hong Kong
summary: The city's stock market closes out its best year for listing activity in a decade, thanks in big part to Chinese technology companies. Shares in one of China's top telemedicine providers surged on their Hong Kong debut Tuesday, reflecting how Chinese technology companies have reinvigorated the city's stock market.

title: Chinese Household Debt Surges Through the Pandemic
summary: The continued rise of real-estate investment left China with the largest increase in global household debt in the first half of the year. China's household debt ballooned in the first half of the year, rising by about $380 billion, according to new Bank for International Settlements data. That increase was almost four times as large as the second-place U.S. And it compounds one of China's biggest economic vulnerabilities.

title: Goldman Sachs to Acquire 100% of China Securities Joint Venture
summary: Firm is first global bank to seek full ownership of its securities business in the country. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is moving to acquire 100% ownership of its securities joint venture in China, deepening its investment in the world's second-largest economy after partnering with a domestic brokerage for 17 years.

title: Chuck Yeager, Pioneer of Supersonic Flight, Dies at 97
summary: He personified era of pilots that moved the U.S. into the jet age. Chuck Yeager, a folksy, hard-living daredevil who was the first aviator to break the sound barrier and became a symbol of bravery for generations of test pilots, astronauts and average Americans, died Monday at the age of 97.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Two Republicans Provide Different Views on Trump's Appeal
summary: Sen. Tom Cotton and William Kristol spoke at The Wall Street Journal's CEO Council Summit. WASHINGTON-GOP Sen. Tom Cotton said that President Trump "has fundamentally transformed some aspects of our party" and argued that the president's hard line on immigration, emphasis on economic growth, and willingness to challenge established media outlets are aspects of the Trump agenda that have staying power.

title: Biden National Security Adviser Sees U.S. Rejoining Iran Nuclear Deal
summary: In addition to Jake Sullivan, Rep. Cedric Richmond-tapped as a senior Biden adviser-also spoke at WSJ's CEO Council Summit. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden's national security adviser said the incoming administration wants to put Iran "back into the box" by rejoining the nuclear deal and forcing Tehran to comply with the terms of the original agreement.

title: Warning Signs Were Missed Ahead of Christchurch Mosque Shootings
summary: Report highlights police failings in granting the gunman a firearms license, concludes intelligence agencies focused too heavily on Islamic extremists. WELLINGTON, New Zealand-Months before Brenton Tarrantmurdered 51 worshipers at two mosques in the New Zealand city of Christchurch, he sought help from hospital staff for wounds to his right eye and thigh from a firearm incident.

title: Georgia Again Certifies Biden's Win
summary: Recertification marks third time Georgia officials counted ballots cast in presidential election. Georgia recertified that President-elect Joe Biden won the state Monday after its second recount, ahead of a looming federal deadline for states to resolve any challenges to their electoral votes.

title: Covid-19 Economy Claimed 128,000 IT Jobs in November
summary: October hiring gains were lost as U.S. employers braced for uncertainty during a coronavirus surge, according to a trade group report. U.S. employers last month cut 128,000 core information-technology jobs, largely erasing hiring gains in October, as companies brace for a second wave of Covid-19 cases, lockdowns and business closures, IT trade group CompTIA reported.

title: Biden Expected to Name Lloyd Austin as Defense Secretary
summary: Austin was commander of U.S. Central Command under President Obama, overseeing forces in the Middle East. President-elect Joe Biden is expected to name Lloyd Austin, a retired Army general who was in charge of military operations in the Middle East under President Obama, as his defense secretary, according to people familiar with the matter, which would make him the first Black defense chief in U.S. history.

title: Canada's Trudeau Confident in Strong Recovery for 2021
summary: Aggressive fiscal policy, consumer cash hoard should propel growth; PM offers caution about business in China. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he anticipates a strong economic recovery to take hold in his country in the middle of next year, aided by government spending and savings that households and businesses have accumulated during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Covid-Aid Negotiators Grapple Over Liability Protections
summary: Lawmakers also seek to iron out deal on state and local aid in roughly $900 billion framework. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers struggled Monday to resolve a long-running dispute over what kind of liability protections to give businesses and other entities operating during the pandemic, one of two big stumbling blocks remaining in their efforts to strike a deal on an emergency relief package.

title: Stitch Fix Hires New Finance Chief From Amazon
summary: Dan Jedda is joining a cohort of former Amazon executives who become CFOs elsewhere. Stitch Fix Inc.'s new finance chief, Dan Jedda, is joining a cohort of former Amazon.com Inc. executives who have left the e-commerce giant to become CFOs elsewhere, strengthening the company's reputation as a breeding ground for finance talent.

title: What Might Unite Washington Behind Biden? Infrastructure
summary: Roads, bridges, airports, subways, broadband-infrastructure might be the way to smash through the political roadblocks. Imagine you are President-elect Joe Biden, and you're looking at a political hot mess when you take office.

title: HHS to Release Hospital-Level Covid-19 Data on Weekly Basis
summary: The agency says it is making the information available in hopes of aiding pandemic response at the local level. The Department of Health and Human Services has released for the first time information on Covid-19 patient counts and the number of full beds at individual hospitals, the most detailed public snapshot yet of the virus's toll on U.S. health care.

title: Uber Sells Self-Driving-Car Unit to Autonomous-Driving Startup
summary: As part of the deal, Uber will make a $400 million investment in Aurora Innovation. Uber Technologies Inc. sold its self-driving-car unit to a Silicon Valley competitor, Aurora Innovation Inc., in the latest business exit by the ride-hailing company as it aims to deliver on a promise to shareholders to become profitable.

title: U.S. Watchdog Will Be Selecting Audits for Inspection More Randomly
summary: Next year, the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board wants to make its target areas in audit inspections less predictable, in part to continue examining the impact of remote work on audits. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board is planning to change the way it picks audits for inspection and conducts its evaluation, part of an effort to assess the impact of remote-work constraints on the quality of audits.

title: Staten Island Ballpark Faces Uncertain Future
summary: New York City had hoped a minor-league baseball team, an outlet mall and a Ferris wheel would revitalize the borough's North Shore. Eight years ago, New York City officials unveiled plans to build one of the world's largest Ferris wheels and a sizable outlet mall to flank the home of a New York Yankees minor-league affiliate on Staten Island-projects they predicted would breathe life into the borough's economically distressed northern shore.

title: Supreme Court Hears Cases on Jewish Property in Nazi Germany, Hungary
summary: Lawyers for the two countries say Jewish heirs' Holocaust-era claims have no place in U.S. courts. WASHINGTON-Germany and Hungary appeared before the Supreme Court on Monday, asking the justices to bar Holocaust-era victims from seeking compensation in U.S. courts for property allegedly confiscated by the Nazi government and its allied regime in Budapest.

title: MSNBC Names Rashida Jones President, Succeeding Phil Griffin
summary: Cable news network's longtime chief to step down at end of January. MSNBC named Rashida Jones as the network's president, people familiar with the matter said, a major shake-up at a news channel that has raised its profile with political coverage but struggled to keep pace with rivals this year.
